author: @parinitasharma9095
text: I figured out how to add arrow keys: def up(event): # Function for up arrow     print("UP ARROW KEY") def down(event): # Function for down arrow     print("DOWN ARROW KEY") def right(event): # Function for right arrow     print("RIGHT ARROW KEY") def left(event): # Function for right arrow     print("LEFT ARROW KEY") root.bind('<Up>', up) # Up arrow key root.bind('<Down>', down) # Down arrow key root.bind('<Right>', right) # Right arrow key root.bind('<Left>', left) # Left arrow key

author: @jacktopus4242
text: I copied exactly what you have done and every time I go to run it it always says- Traceback (most recent call last):   File "project_pete.py", line 54, in <module>     if key_press.lower() == 'w': NameError: name 'key_press' is not defined   if anyone could please help?   here is my script-   import RPi.GPIO as gpio import time import sys import Tkinter as tk  def init():     gpio.setmode(gpio.BOARD)     gpio.setup(7, gpio.OUT)     gpio.setup(11, gpio.OUT)     gpio.setup(13, gpio.OUT)     gpio.setup(15, gpio.OUT)  def forward(tf):     gpio.output(7, False)     gpio.output(11, True)     gpio.output(13, False)     gpio.output(15, True)     time.sleep(tf)     gpio.cleanup()  def reverse(tf):     gpio.output(7, True)     gpio.output(11, False)     gpio.output(13, True)     gpio.output(15, False)     time.sleep(tf)     gpio.cleanup()  def left(tf):     gpio.output(7, False)     gpio.output(11, True)     gpio.output(13, True)     gpio.output(15, False)     time.sleep(tf)     gpio.cleanup()  def right(tf):     gpio.output(7, True)     gpio.output(11, False)     gpio.output(13, False)     gpio.output(15, True)     time.sleep(tf)     gpio.cleanup()     def key_input(event):     init()     print ('Key:'), event.char     key_press = event.char     st = 0.030  if key_press.lower() == 'w':     forward(st) elif key_press.lower() == 's':     reverse(st) elif key_press.lower() == 'a':     left(st) elif key_press.lower() == 'd':     right(st) else:     pass   command = tk.Tk() command.bind('<KeyPress>', key_input) command.mainloop()

author: @princeibrahim1
text: Umm, so I'm following your tutorial in 2016, I know it's too late to reply to the problem of pressing any other key than w,a,s,d,q,e. When any other key is pressed, motors start to spin. To solve that, inside else: instead of "pass" you need to write "gpio.cleanup()"... :)

author: @robertpendergast2620
text: IMPORTANT NOTE: I missed the statement on your written tutorial that Tkinter would not work on a "headless" RPi. I was attempting to use ssh without success operating the robot.  Then I opened the RPi GUI (picture interface) remotely (I use xrdp and Microsoft Remote desktop), opened terminal and ran the program and the Tk box opened and the robot ran!! I changed the time from 0.030 to 0.30 and the little guy now hauls a**.

author: @rycarr
text: You can track when a user releases a key by binding <KeyRelease> I have an example here, note my GPIO pins are set different and I'm handling movement slightly different. Code should work, python may complain about indention, all indention should be 4 spaces or 8 spaces when inside an if/else https://docs.google.com/document/d/1_ge-LtmKPByz_3mOjyKbii6znmo5kLVRZOKK_MwTy20/edit?usp=sharing
